raw_text:
Election 'could be terror target'
 
 Terrorists might try to target the UK in the run-up to the election, London's most senior police officer has said.
 
 Sir Ian Blair said terror groups would remember the effect of the Madrid bomb on Spain's general election last year. Other potential targets were the royal wedding and the UK's presidency of the European Union and G8, he said. He refused to say if there was specific information about the risk of a pre-poll attack. No 10 was similarly cautious but said the threat was real.
 
 The comments come after Tony Blair defended his controversial anti-terror proposals, warning that it would be wrong to wait for an attack before acting. Sir Ian told a meeting of the Metropolitan Police Authority it would be "unwise" to speculate about whether there was specific information about risks of a pre-election attack. But he said: "Terrorists have long memories. They understand what happened in Madrid and know what the impact of that was on the Spanish electorate.
 
 "This year we are responsible for the EU presidency, presidency of the G8, a royal wedding and a general election. "There are obvious and enormous targets which we have to deal with." Sir Ian said the debate over anti-terror plans was one for politicians, not the police, who would enforce any new powers.
 
 Home Secretary Charles Clarke has also warned that a Madrid-style pre-election bombing could happen in the UK too. Asked about Sir Ian's comments, the prime minister's official spokesman said: "We believe the threat is real." The spokesman declined to comment on whether the security services had received specific intelligence relating to a possible attack during the election campaign. He said No 10 did not disclose any security advice they received. Earlier, writing in the Daily Telegraph, the prime minister conceded that plans to detain suspects under house arrest without trial were "difficult issues for any government". The Commons has approved the measures despite considerable opposition, with the government's majority more than halved as 32 Labour rebels joined Tory and Lib Dem opposition. But Mr Blair insisted: "There is no greater civil liberty than to live free from terrorist attack."
 
 Tory leader Michael Howard has accused Mr Blair of steamrolling the house arrest plans and of "using national security for political point scoring". Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy says that the plan is a further example of Labour's "authoritarian" response to crises. The Prevention of Terrorism Bill proposes "control orders", which as well as house arrest could impose curfews, tagging or bans on telephone and internet use. They would replace current powers to detain foreign terror suspects without trial, which the law lords have ruled against. But critics are concerned that it would be the home secretary and not judges who decided to impose control orders. The plans face further Commons scrutiny on Monday before passing to the Lords.
llama3.2:1b: Terrorists may target the UK in the run-up to the election, with senior police officer Sir Ian Blair warning of a potential attack due to previous incidents such as the Madrid bomb and royal wedding targets. Home Secretary Charles Clarke has also expressed concerns about the threat. The government plans to approve the Prevention of Terrorism Bill's house arrest measures despite opposition, but Prime Minister Tony Blair insists there is no greater civil liberty than not being targeted by terrorism.
llama3.2:3b: Terrorists may target the UK in the run-up to the election, London's police chief said, citing a Madrid-style bombing as a possible threat. The Home Secretary also warned of a similar risk. The government has approved anti-terror plans despite opposition from Labour rebels and critics accusing it of "authoritarian" tactics.
gemma2:2b: Terrorists may target UK during election season due to past events like Madrid bombing.  Police say this is based on terrorists' memories of the impact. Concerns are being raised about pre-election attacks, with Home Secretary Clarke warning of potential threats. PM Blair defends anti-terror plans and their implementation. Opposition parties criticize the new plan for house arrest without trial, accusing the government of using national security for political gains. The bill now awaits scrutiny by the Lords before final approval.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Terrorists in the UK are likely to target potential election candidates and figures from other political parties. They have already used a similar tactic with Spain's general election last year, leading Sir Ian Blair, London's most senior police officer, to say that terror groups would remember the Madrid bomb attack on Spanish elections last year. No 10 is similarly cautious but still warns of possible pre-election attacks. The UK is also responsible for EU presidency, G8 presidency, royal wedding and general election. There are clear targets that must be dealt with: Madrid-style attacks are a possibility too. Home Secretary Charles Clarke has warned that the UK's plans to detain suspects under house arrest without trial could lead to more attacks.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Police officer suggests UK could be targeted in election run-up due to recent terrorist incidents, including Spain's Madrid bombing last year. Calls for increased security measures following Tony Blair's defense of controversial anti-terrorism proposals.
qwen2.5:3b: Terrorists may target the UK during election preparations, warns London's police chief. Sir Ian Blair cites the 2004 Madrid bombings on Spain's general election as precedent. Potential targets include the royal wedding and EU presidency/G8 meetings. No specific information about an upcoming attack was provided. The government asserts a real threat exists but refuses to disclose intelligence details. Home Secretary Charles Clarke also warns of potential pre-election bombing in UK, similar to Madrid. Debates continue over anti-terror plans, including controversial house arrest measures without trial.
opencoder:1.5b: The election could indeed be a target for terrorist attacks. Terrorists might try to target the UK in the run-up to the election, London's most senior police officer has said. Sir Ian Blair, who refused to say if there was specific information about the risk of a pre-poll attack, said that the threat was real. The comments come after Tony Blair defended his controversial anti-terror proposals, warning that it would be wrong to wait for an attack before acting. The prime minister's official spokesman said: "We believe the threat is real." Mr Clarke also warned that plans to detain suspects under house arrest without trial were "difficult issues for any government". With a majority of supporters supporting this, the government's security and enforcement powers have been reduced. But Mr Blair insisted: "There is no greater civil liberty than to live free from terrorist attack."

* Terrorists might try to target the UK in the run-up to the election, London's most senior police officer has said.
* Sir Ian Blair said terror groups would remember the effect of the Madrid bomb on Spain's general election last year. Other potential targets were the royal wedding and the UK's presidency of the European Union and G8, he said. He refused to say if there was specific information about the risk of a pre-poll attack. No 10 was similarly cautious but said the threat was real.
* The comments come after Tony Blair defended his controversial anti-terror proposals, warning that it would be wrong to wait for an attack before acting. Sir Ian told a meeting of the Metropolitan Police Authority it would be "unwise" to speculate about whether there was specific information about risks of a pre-election attack. But he said: "Terrorists have long memories. They understand what happened in Madrid and know what the impact of that was on the Spanish electorate."
* The debate over anti-terror plans is one for politicians, not the police, who would enforce any new powers. Sir Ian warned that a Madrid-style pre-election bombing could happen in the UK too. Asked about Sir Ian's comments, the prime minister's official spokesman said: "We believe the threat is real." The spokesperson declined to comment on whether the security services had received specific intelligence relating to a possible attack during the election campaign. * Home Secretary Charles Clarke has also warned that a Madrid-style pre-election bombing could happen in the UK too. Asked about Sir Ian's comments, the prime minister's official spokesman said: "There is no greater civil liberty than to live free from terrorist attack."
* Tory leader Michael Howard has accused Mr Blair of steamrolling the house arrest plans and of using national security for political point scoring. Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy says that the plan is a further example of Labour's "authoritarian" response to crises. The plans face further Commons scrutiny on Monday before passing to the Lords.

tinyllama:1.1b: The text mentions Ellection 'could be terror target' and warns of potential for terror attacks during the election campaign, including pre-poll attacks such as Madrid bombing (2004) and the UK presidency of the European Union and G8 (2005), which are identified as targets by terrorist groups. The text also mentions specific information about the risk of a pre-election attack, and warns that political point scoring and authoritarianism are being used as justification for the bill's passage through Parliament.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, according to the text, the UK is a prime target for terror attacks in the run-up to the general election. This could occur due to the presence of previous Madrid bombings, Spain's presidency of the European Union and G8, or the royal wedding. There are also concerns about potential pre-election attacks on the home front and international ones. Some politicians, including Tony Blair, are worried that speculating about such threats would be too early to act.
phi:2.7b: London's most senior police officer warned that terrorists might target the UK in the run-up to the election, citing Madrid' s attack as a potential inspiration. Other possible targets include the royal wedding, the UK's presidency of the EU and G8, and the general election. No specific information about pre-poll attacks is available, but the threat is real. The debate over anti-terror plans is for politicians to decide, not the police, who will enforce any new powers. Home Secretary Charles Clarke also warned that a Madrid-style pre-election bombing could happen in the UK too.

Other potential targets include the royal wedding and the UK's presidency of the European Union and G8. The threat is real, says Sir Ian Blair, although he refused to say if there was specific information about the risk of a pre-poll attack. However, Home Secretary Charles Clarke has warned that a Madrid-style pre-election bombing could happen in the UK too. The government's plans to detain suspects under house arrest without trial are controversial, with Labour rebels joining Tories and Lib Dems in opposition.
hermes3:3b: Election potentially targeted by terrorists, warned UK's most senior police officer. Refers to Madrid bomb effect on Spanish general election last year.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: London's most senior police officer, Sir Ian Blair, warned that terrorists might try to target the UK in the run-up to an election, remembering the impact of the Madrid bomb on Spain's general election last year. Other potential targets included the royal wedding, the UK's presidency of the European Union and G8, and other events happening this year. The debate over anti-terror plans is for politicians, not the police, who would enforce any new powers. Home Secretary Charles Clarke also warned that a Madrid-style pre-election bombing could happen in the UK, and the prime minister acknowledged the difficulties of detaining suspects under house arrest without trial. The Prevention of Terrorism Bill proposes control orders, which could replace current detainment methods and face further scrutiny in Commons and the Lords.
chatgpt-4o-latest: London's top police officer, Sir Ian Blair, warned that terrorists might target the UK ahead of the general election, citing the impact of the Madrid bombings on Spain's election. Other potential targets include the royal wedding and the UK's EU and G8 presidencies. While he did not confirm specific intelligence, he emphasized the ongoing threat. Prime Minister Tony Blair defended his anti-terror proposals, including controversial house arrest measures, arguing that preventing attacks is a priority. The Commons approved the measures despite significant opposition, with critics, including Tory leader Michael Howard and Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, accusing Blair of using national security for political gain. The Prevention of Terrorism Bill, which introduces "control orders" such as curfews and tagging, faces further scrutiny before moving to the Lords.
stablelm2:1.6b: Terrorists may target the UK in the lead-up to an election according to London's senior police officer, Sir Ian Blair. He cites the example of the Madrid general election attack and other potential targets such LONDON ROYAL WEDDING & EU Presidency/G8 meetings, as well as a pre-election bomb. Home Secretary Charles Clarke also warns of a possible "Madrid-style" pre-lection attack. Prime Minister's official spokesman states that the threat is real despite not revealing specific intelligence received from security services. The Prevention of Terrorism Bill is proposed with control orders replacing current powers to detain foreign terror suspects without trial, subjecting home secretary to decide on control orders instead of judges, a matter of concern for critics.
granite3.1-dense:2b: London's top police officer, Sir Ian Blair, warned of potential terror threats to the UK during its election campaign, citing historical impacts like the 2004 Madrid bombing that swayed Spain's general election. He highlighted the country's responsibilities for EU presidency, G8 leadership, a royal wedding, and the upcoming general election as high-risk targets. Sir Ian emphasized that while the threat is real, he wouldn't provide specific information about pre-election attacks. The Home Secretary, Charles Clarke, echoed this concern, warning of possible Madrid-style bombings in the UK. Prime Minister Tony Blair defended his government's anti-terror proposals, stating that waiting for an attack before acting would be wrong. However, he acknowledged the controversial nature of house arrest without trial provisions, which have been approved despite significant opposition. Critics, including Tory leader Michael Howard and Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy, accuse Blair of politicizing national security and advancing an authoritarian response to crises. The Prevention of Terrorism Bill proposes control orders, which could impose curfews, tagging, or internet bans in addition to house arrest for suspected terrorists. These measures are set to undergo further parliamentary scrutiny before moving to the House of Lords.
reference: Sir Ian said the debate over anti-terror plans was one for politicians, not the police, who would enforce any new powers.Sir Ian Blair said terror groups would remember the effect of the Madrid bomb on Spain's general election last year.Sir Ian told a meeting of the Metropolitan Police Authority it would be "unwise" to speculate about whether there was specific information about risks of a pre-election attack.Terrorists might try to target the UK in the run-up to the election, London's most senior police officer has said.No 10 was similarly cautious but said the threat was real.Other potential targets were the royal wedding and the UK's presidency of the European Union and G8, he said.Tory leader Michael Howard has accused Mr Blair of steamrolling the house arrest plans and of "using national security for political point scoring".He refused to say if there was specific information about the risk of a pre-poll attack.He said No 10 did not disclose any security advice they received.Asked about Sir Ian's comments, the prime minister's official spokesman said: "We believe the threat is real."
